content:
- 17 -
衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
of the National Health Service Act, implemented in 1948, and good personal relations with bacteriologists throughout the country. For these reasons it has been possible to centralize all information on the salmonella problem at the Central Public Health Laboratory.
The function of the National Salmonella Centre is to collect information on the distribution of salmonella serotypes within the country, to have a knowledge of the distribution of types in the world, to disseminate information on technical methods, to teach others the methods of salmonella identification, to investigate the antigenic structure and biochemical reactions etc. of all new types, and to prepare and supply diagnostic material to other laboratories.
In the United Kingdom the last-named of these functions (the preparation and supply of diagnostic material to other laboratories) is carried out mainly by the Standards Laboratory for Serological Reagents in respect of sera, and by the National Collection of Type Cultures in respect of bacterial cultures. The National Salmonella Centre may therefore be regarded as consisting of three component units, the Salmonella Reference Laboratory, the Standards Laboratory for Serological Reagents, and the National Collection of Type Cultures, all located at the Central Public Health Laboratory, Colindale, London. 140.112:213.82
In addition to the Salmonella Reference Laboratory at Colindale there is a reference laboratory in Glasgow, Scotland, and a poultry reference laboratory at the Veterinary Research Station, Weybridge. The three laboratories work in close collaboration, any new, unusual or difficult strains being sent to Colindale. The annual returns from the three laboratories are exchanged.
The Salmonella Reference Laboratory receives any culture which it is considered could be a salmonella, salmonella cultures requiring identification, and salmonella cultures which may be giving equivocal results.
The strains are sent in by all types of laboratories, and so cover a wide field. The usual laboratories are:
diagnostic hospital laboratories public health laboratories private laboratories veterinary laboratories food investigation laboratories.
國史饭 Academia Historica
89 :selected:

衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
of the National Health Service Act, implemented in 1948, and good personal relations
with bacteriologists throughout the country. For these reasons it has been possible
to centralize all information on the salmonella problem at the Central Public
Health Laboratory.
The function of the National Salmonella Centre is to collect information on
the distribution of salmonella serotypes within the country, to have a knowledge
of the distribution of types in the world, to disseminate information on technical
methods, to teach others the methods of salmonella identification, to investigate
the antigenic structure and biochemical reactions etc. of all new types, and to
prepare and supply diagnostic material to other laboratories.
In the United Kingdom the last-named of these functions (the preparation and
supply of diagnostic material to other laboratories) is carried out mainly by the
Standards Laboratory for Serological Reagents in respect of sera, and by the
National Collection of Type Cultures in respect of bacterial cultures. The National
Salmonella Centre may therefore be regarded as consisting of three component units,
the Salmonella Reference Laboratory, the Standards Laboratory for Serological
Reagents, and the National Collection of Type Cultures, all located at the Central
Public Health Laboratory, Colindale, London.
In addition to the Salmonella Reference Laboratory at Colindale there is a
reference laboratory in Glasgow, Scotland, and a poultry reference laboratory at
the Veterinary Research Station, Weybridge. The three laboratories work in close
collaboration, any new, unusual or difficult strains being sent to Colindale. The
annual returns from the three laboratories are exchanged.
The Salmonella Reference Laboratory receives any culture which it is considered
could be a salmonella, salmonella cultures requiring identification, and salmonella
cultures which may be giving equivocal results.
The strains are sent in by all types of laboratories, and so cover a wide
field. The usual laboratories are:
diagnostic hospital laboratories
public health laboratories
private laboratories
veterinary laboratories
food investigation laboratories.
